content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is a ridiculous PvE RTS game, aka players against AI. Everything you'd expect from a standard RTS is cranked up to eleven.There are MANY different structures. There are MANY different ships to build. Several factions have specialized ships and abilities. You can have fleets in the hundreds and micro every individual ship across a galaxy-sized map. But you are all pitted against a computer. With near infinite resources and reflexes, the odds are heavily stacked against you and that's where the fun and challenge comes in. You will defeat them through pure strategy and decision making. Claim key targets, and do it quickly before the force of a billion suns crush your base.Amazing soundtrack. Fantastic and complex game. Has up to 8 players for multiplayer. Graphics are lackluster but probably necessary to prevent massive lag or crashing trying to render thousands of particle effects and animations at once.It should be noted games are very long, even on the shortest settings. Expect time frames for a single campaign to range from a couple hours to weeks. That along with its extremely steep learning curve means this game requires some serious dedication to go places. Multiplayer especially requires dedicated play sessions; while it does have a dropin/drop out function, it can be difficult to manage when players are shifting around and losing track of the game state often.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Ai War: Fleet Command is a game that takes some time to get into. The incredibly long tutorial is one thing, but this universe plays like a tabletop board game in the sense that all of your actions lead to the game becoming increasingly difficult. The game though, with time becomes an experience that cannot be found in most strategy games. Instead of giving you an entire empire to control, you have one planet in a large galaxy. Your single planet has nothing on it. The thrill of building up an intricate turret system and infrastructure whilst evading enemy patrols and ambushes is worth the entry price (which is very low.) Taking over your first planet which will be hard is an achievement that you will remember.Keep in mind however this game is tough. You will have lots of questions at first like "How do I launch nukes?" "How do I upgrade starships?" and "What the hell is the AI readiness meter?"With some time however, this game becomes a blast. I recommend it for people that are willing to put some time in and learn a new game. However, if you were looking for a casual RTS, this is not the one.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												AI War has ruined other RTSes for me.  I used to do coop games versus AI in Starcraft and Company of Heroes and such.  AI War is so much better than any other RTS I've played at PVE that I can't go back.There are a lot of difficulty knobs you can turn to tune the experience to be as challenging as you want.  This alone makes it vastly superior to a lot of other games.  They've done a good job preventing cheesy strategies like sending an SCV to kite the enemy workers.  The random elements mean you can't really play exactly the same way twice.The UI can be frustrating, especially early on.  The game has a lot of information to present the player, some of which is not obviously useful to a new player.  There are a lot of weird controls, like holding down 4 and drag selecting to select only tier 4 units.  I got used to this, but the UI could definitely use some work.Not a big fan of the ship art.  This is mostly fine since I typically play zoomed out far enough I'm only seeing the tactical icons for ships anyway.Overall, though, if you like PVE RTS games you will probably enjoy this one.

												Graphics aren't great and the SFX aren't either. But the music is good and the gameplay is phenomenal. With a tremondous amount of customizability in terms of complexity, difficulty, and scale this game can adapt for many playstyles. You must come up with a long-term strategy and be able to adapt it to changing situations. Mindlessly attacking or an having inflexible plan will lead to your demise. The AI is far more transparent than in most games, but that does not make it worse. On the contrary, the game is built around controlling your antagonization of the AI, and it is more than capable tactically.Do, however, start with the tutorials.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												It took nearly 3 games over the course of 6ish months. It took a very specific setup involving no expansions. It took a dedicated push to really give this game a shot. But one day, this game "clicked" and now I can't stop thinking about it.AI War: Fleet Command is the game for strategy fans who want to challenge their preconcpetions of what an RTS is all about. Just because an RTS has no multiplayer doesn't mean it isn't hard, challenging or enjoyable.The AI in this game is second to none and puts AAA RTS titles to shame. It sneak attacks, it flanks, it understands your weaknesses and exploits them. These intelligent little buggers will constantly keep you on your toes and have you wondering why no other game is like it. On top of being clever, the AI is also highly customizable now with the expansions and there are plenty of opponents to take on. Do you want to take on an AI that will send waves of units frequently to your doorstep? Or perhaps you would prefer an AI who turtles up and defends their planets to the death. Why not combine two different AI types and go nuts? Or even go random and try and figure out the AI's strategy and adapt. The choice is yours.Tactically, the game is pretty good, with unit positioninging being critical in both battles and in general (last thing you want is an undefended homeworld getting sniped by the AI). Where the game outshines any other though is in strategy. No two games are alike, and even in the fairly simple early game (where my 3 games spent most of their time since 2 ended prematurely) the games felt entirely different with a large variety of units, structures and AI tactics to counter. 30+ hours in and I am still seeing new units I haven't seen before. This is a game you will be playing for the long haul once it grips you.Be warned however - this game is not for everyone. Even for a fan of this kind of game like myself, it took a little while before everything suddenly fell into place and the game suddenly became a masterpiece in my mind. If you aren't sure... why not try the demo? The demo lets you play all the tutorials, a decent amount of the single player game and you can even test multiplayer to see if you can connect to others properly. There is no reason not to give this game a try for free; heck, even the demo could give you a good 10 hours of gameplay.Highly recommended. Years after release the game is still frequently updated (with an update literally just yesterday) and a new expansion is coming. It is currently on sale. Please buy if you are interested, you will love it if it is for you.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												TL;DR  If you really love strategy, definitely get the game.The first thing that really surprises me is that the creator charge dirt cheap prices even without a sale for the bundle. Arcen could easily charge around $30 for the game. I bought the game a long time ago and it was sitting on my library. I actually bought the game and all its expansions twice just for the heck of it. Here is my experience with the game.The game starts deceptively simple. It looks like something that is a cross from sins of a solar empire and supreme commander but the game is a whole different beast. The plethora of options on how you want to play your game would ensure that no two game would ever go the same. This gives the game close to endless replayability. The game is so flexible that you can play it as either a click-fest RTS or a grand-strategy/4x that can be pausable. The ship variety and all the other nasty stuff you encounter on your game can be set by you.So what exactly is the game like? It is about you against the AI. You are the commander of a group of humans that have been driven almost to extinction when the AI that was used to control your war machines during the civil war has gone turbo. The AI have driven humanity to the brink of extinction and then turned its eye on other alien worlds. Your duty is to survive and destroy the AI. It isn't an easy task. The more systems you attack, the AI's attention will slowly turn towards you. If you get too greedy, the AI can easily squash you out like a bug in no time. You must pick your targets carefully while trying to make it look like you are still an insignificant threat. You have to keep it up until the next thing the AI knows, you will be knocking on its doorstep and destroying its homeworld.The game really gives you that feeling of hopelessnes and dread. You feel wary about your every move, knowing the AI can send out its best ships and destroy your little rebellion. In terms of ship variety, there are tons of ships available to you. From the staple fighter/bomber/missile frigates and your basic starships to really nasty ships like the leech starship that can turn destroyed enemy ships in to zombie ships that will fight for you. Getting all the expansion adds a lot since every expansion adds layers upon layers of ships/buildings/factions that you will encounter in the universe. battles are very strategic, at first it may seem that you can get away by piling up a huge blob of ships and overpowering the AI but it doesn't work that way. The ships have different hull types with different weaknesses plus there are different tier of ships and structures. You can't just go in to a system and overrun it with your ships. Some system may have mines that will rip your ships to shreds. Some have Mass Drivers that can easily turn your starships to scrap metal. The different variety of ships and structures are just too many to count. The game is not your ordinary clickfest RTS. The game is as strategic as chess. You need to identify your targets, see what things can easily rip your ships to shreds, which structures you have to destroy before bringing in your other ships. The game is just so deep!I haven't scratched the surface of the game yet. I played more on my GOG version since I had all the expansions there first. The game is super hard and super rewarding. You wouldn't regret getting it. It can be intimidating but just keep on pushing forward and you will finally see how great the game is. The AI in this game is one of the best ever. It will keep you on your toes. It will always be a step ahead of you. It will make you feel anxious about your every move. It will destroy your carefully laid plans without even using a lot of its resources. This is one of the best strategy games ever.Sidenote: Dev customer service is actually pretty good. I bought 2 expansions direct from them and they actually provided me with a steam key and they respond pretty fast.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												This is a fantastic 4x RTS Grand strategy game. The mechanics are very deep, and there are limitless strategies you can decide to use in order to accomplish your goal or take out the enemy. The game is pretty difficult to get the hang of, but once you do it's a really fun time, and you can always learn new things. content:
Posted: November 25, 2010
												Awesome RTS. Not so much about base building or resource-gathering, but you do a little bit of resource gathering (handled similarly to Total Annihilation), and a little bit of base building, but mostly (MOSTLY) just for harvesting resources.The best thing about this game is the AI. The big selling point is that real-world tactics like baiting and decoys ACTUALLY WORK. oh. And the AI will use those same tactics against you.PaulC and I have spent many hours beating the computer into submission, and still kept going back for more. If you like RTSes, games that make you work for a win, or just innovative stuff that doesn't follow the same old archetypes, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2013
												I don't usually like RTS games, but this one is just plain fun.It's got really slick controls, decent graphics and great music. Lots of build complexity with not only several different kinds of ships and starships (bigger) but different ranks of each ship and unlockable (by capturing things) ships.Did I mention a lot of ships? In most RTSes you get maybe 50 to 100 for your army...phhhftt thats no army... within an hour of a campaign on AI War you might be fighting battles of 1000 vs 1000 or more.Very gratifying.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2010
												One of the best strategy games I've ever played. The concept is you are pretty much a rebel faction fighting against an AI faction that has taken over a bunch of planets. You will need to think and plan on which planets to take over for resources or for a strategic purpose because each negative action against the AI will make them more aware of you and fight you harder. The only downsides is you need a friend or two to play with and some time. Its highly unlikely you will finish a game in one sitting. Otherwise, its amazing that with all the units and building going on, the developers have found a way to reduce micromanagement to almost zero. Really interesting little additions as well such as attacks from the AI every hour or so that you need to stop what you are doing and prepare for.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2012
												That game is weird. I don't really know where to start with it.First, it's in 2D, kinda like Space Pirates and Zombies.Second, it's hard. You can lose your units very quickly, and then the enemy will counter-attack, leading to your loss. Consider units caps as a suggestion if you want to live.Third, the enemy is an IA. Mostly passive, she's easily predictable.Fourth, that game gives a weird feeling. Like there's something missing, like an atmosphere, something to make the game unique. And the music doesn't have any personality either.Fifth, expect a lot a quick save/quick load. Even while doing the tutorial, I had to load 5 times. And I still didn't finished it.That game isn't for casuals. The enemy will be mostly passive, but once provoked, it will easily wipe your base. Expect spending a lot of time buildings all the ships you can.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This is probably my favorite game of the last 10 years. It has an extremely high learning curve. I started playing it, and gave it up as too complex, twice before I gave it the time it needed. It has an extremely well-paced and thorough tutorial, which I recommend you play. The community at the developer's website is an amazing resource, and the developers themselves are frequently the first people to answer a question you post.There is a tremendous amount of depth, strategic choice, and content in AI War. It's different every game. I've played for over 150 hours and am still seeing new content and finding out different ways to approach the AI.Make no mistake, it's a brutal and difficult slog and you will lose many, many times before you finally defeat the AI. Oh, it is so sweet when you finally do.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												The best ever grand strategy game I have played. Takes a while to get used to the interface, but after that it is amazing. A mix of 4x, and Tower Defence. The AI in is is absolutely brutal, very cunning. In one game it slipped past my forward defenses with a fleet of cloaked fighters, they must have been hidden for a while at my home planet. It continued to batter my forward defenses with wave upon wave of ships, of which I could barely keep producing my own ships to counter. Then de-cloaked his fighters and destroyed my four fleet factories. In the process stopping my re-inforcements to the frontlies and scuppering my supply. In the same second, the AI informed me that 30,000+ ships were on their way to the forntline in 2 minutes 50 seconds to obliterate my small 3000+ fleet and 100+ turrets. Defenceless I lasted out for another 10 minutes of frantically trying to rebuild defences to stop the other 25,000 ships (5,000 has been destroyed at the frontline) gunning for my home planet. That'll teach me to♥♥♥♥♥♥it off too much. Seriously give  it a go. Doon't let the dated graphics put you off, the gameplay and strategy options are absolutely outstanding. It'll get you hooked and you'll not see your family for days. That moment when the tables turn and your in the position to finally win is priceless.  And what is even better that its even harder on co-op. 9.5/10

												It's a 2D Star Ruler. If Sins of a Solar Empire is a sort of fake 2.5D, and Homeworld is a proper 3D game, then AI is to Homeworld, what Terraria is to Minecraft.It's fun and brutal, and the AI learns and adapts procedurally, it's not designed to be fair, it's training Skynet. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2012
												A wonderful co-op focused strategic game. The things you can do, sometimes must do to actually win a campaign are pretty diverse, and the game offers you plenty of choices to work with. Choices start in setting up your campaign, letting the host set the difficulty and type of each of the two AIs, the type and difficulty of minor factions in the game (which, with all the expanions, make for quite a few), special AI plots, some extra AI behaviour, the map you play on, generated based on seed, your home system (dictating what special ship you get to start with), even letting a player start with multiple home worlds, adjusting AI difficulty and ship number caps accordingly.Another thing of note, aside from the juicy diversity and fun gameplay, is the music. And I'm quite picky with my music.Challenging and fun, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good strategy game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Few games in this life have something very special about them. The earlier Elder Scrolls games and a few of the Legend of Zelda titles were what I consider 'Special'. Not many games anymore have the same magic that games used to. AI War is a different story. Everthing about this game, the sound effects, the art, the music, and most importantly, the gamplay, are all extremely special. I would rather be sitting at the main menu of this game than play almost any other game I can think of. The gameplay ranges from mild to wild. You can set it to easy and win a game with a little bit of time and not much difficulty. If you set the difficulty to 10, out of nowhere, you will see 20,000 enemy ships lauch into your planet and destroy you faster than you can say "Huh?". I cannot stress enough how fantastic this games is. Whether you want to kill 10 minutes or 10 years, this will be one of the most rewarding games you will ever play!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												The first glance of this game may scare some people, yet after spending a bit of time learning how they can be used to actually  manage the massive numbers of units late-game. However they end up being a friend any RTS gamer will be quite fond of.  Selecting a single unit among thousands simplified along with the instant access to any production. Really amazed this game took so long to hear about and confounded by how so little people know of it's existance.  If you like strategy and you give this game a chance, the reward is a prespective change from the copycat rts layout used in every RTS I can even think of.  Really allows for easier control of a larger area and numerous fleets and production facilities.The difficulty options, once explored and realized, turn out to be the greatest thing about this games difficulty, adjusted will always keep your skill in check, a train-as-you-play type of learning for people who find the game too hard or as a constant test to push your skill a step further each game you experience.True to the definition of outstanding and unique gameplay.

Posted: September 26, 2012
												Instead of trying to play better than your opponent, AI War is about exploiting the quirks of the games AI, which are explained to you. Managing its numerical states while still making war progress is the entire game and it feels inventive, fascinating and above all else, intimate in a really cool way. The game itself is overwhelming and imposing, but it's ok once you kind of loosen up and stop trying to understand things like you would in Starcraft. Just get into the flow and save your brainpower for dealing with the AI and how it might react.The game was still far too clever for me, but for those few hours I did play, it felt amazing to look in onto such genius design.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2011
												I bought this game back in 2009. The developers threw out the challenge that techincally speaking putting all the AI difficulty settings (of which there is a lot of modifiers) on their hardest would make the game literally impossible to beat. Challenge Accepted.The year is now 2013 me and my friend have played countless battles been close to victory only to be denied in epic and adrenaline pumping ways. At points we have refused to speak on our voice comms out of paranoia that the AI might actually be listening to our war plans. The AI seems to have a counter for most things even luring you into a false sense of security.There is a steep yet quick to overcome learning curve to this game. You will probably need a few hours just to get used to the fundamentals of the game (even 4 years on where expansions and still frequent updates come out I am still coming across things I have never encoutnered before).I would really recommend this game to anyone who though Total Annihlation's unit cap was insane as this game simply does not have one (well where the AI is concerned anyway) Million unit waves will onslaught you. Of course this is a high demand on your CPU and Network transmit so if you play with friends LAN is best or certainly do not do too many players on the internet unless you have awesome speeds.AI war pushes your CPU into a blackhole of awesomeness. And leaves the player on the vent horizon pondering when his doom shall innevitably come.Be warned though however great you are at strategy games, your skill means nothing here.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2013
												You can't love everything about Arcen.  Its a game dev that doesn't care too much about what fans say or think. In another words, there is only one way to really play this game. They give you options but none that change how it must be played. You must not take all the planets, you cannot conquer your way to victory (unless the diff is set way down) It has a pretty steep learning curve (expect to lose the first few, even after a few hours). This is a game that also is best played with a friend or 2. The AI cheat, they are allowed to cheat, and they are given lots of advantages (like having virtually unlimited ships while you are very limited). Its a challenging game (try setting the difficulty down from the start), in depth, simple graphics, and can be very fun. Get it when its 5 bucks or less.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I haven't played this game for a while (and that was on Impulse version, so no Steam gameplay hours). That said, if you have enough time to learn this game, you definitely should get it. I'd say it takes between two to eight hours to learn the game enough to really start enjoying it. Most of the UI is behind keyboard shortcuts (though you can probably *kind of* do without them), and there's so, so many shortcuts, many of them basically mandatory. Well, for convenient playing, in any case, since you can probably manage without, but it's going to take at least twice as long to play the actual game without the shortcuts.Now, assuming you can manage the UI, the game is excellent. The point of the game is you're against two AI's, which are also AI:s ingame. As in, you're in control of human survivors, surrounded by two mighty AIs. Initially, you're not worth the AI's attention, and will barely receive any attacks. As you expand and destroy AI bases, they will  start to consider  you a threat, and their attacks will get more serious.The genius of the game is this: AI and you are not equal. The AI has vastly more troops, and controls nearly all of the map. You're initially in control of a few human survivors, and the only reason you're surviving is  you're not worth the AI's attention. As you begin to draw more attention the threat increases. Your goal is to wipe out the AI's, but you (probably) cannot simply conquer everything, as that would lead to an overwhelming AI aggression. You have to choose the best strategic targets to conquer, and leave the rest to AIs.Though the game is real time, there is usually no hurry. AI War is really more a puzzle game than an actual RTS. A single playthrough can easily take more than eight hours on standard settings.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2013
												Part RTS, Part 4x, AI War has you fighting over solar systems on a randomly generated map. Each node on the map is connected to various other ones, and each node has its own little solar system map. You build various bases and units, upgrading technology and mining the various systems for resources, however what makes this game unlike any other in the genra is that it is simply you vs the ai and how the computer reacts depends on what you do. To simplify it the AI gets progressivly more difficult the more nodes you take over, meaning that you really have to be careful about what you take over, as each node offers diffrent bonuses. If you progress too far without growth and careful thought you will find yourself destroyed by a super powerful AI. It is a VERY interesting and unique game, give it a shot, it's worth 10$, or more if you end up likeing it.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												A fascinating, experimental strategy game. It's almost puzzle-like--you can't afford to conquer everything, so you have to very carefully pick the systems you want and figure out how to skip over and possibly neutralize the ones you won't take. And of course, each system presents its own little tactical puzzle. If you enjoy staring at a screen for a while trying to decide what your next move will be, I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												AI War is an incredible 4x game. The amount of depth and detail put into it is just astounding, it ensures that each game is a whole new experience. The game pits you against two AI commanders, they control every planet in the universe but yours. They have hundreds of thousands of ships and you are just starting on your planet. The AI fights you by sending waves to your planets, to counteract this you can use your fleets or turrets. Think RTS with Tower Defense as a viable strategy for defense. The game is massive, the research pages offer a plethora of options making literally hundreds of strategies. One game you may be using large fortresses to defend your planets, while another you may be using turrets or even a dedicated fleet. The music and sound is decent, but nothing incredible. It adds a nice tone to the game but isn't something that I would buy the OST to. AI War's visuals are fairly minimalistic, however they serve their purpose and aren't too bad once accustomed to the visual style of the game. Definitely not a downside in the slightest. I personally fairly enjoy seeing graphics that can present the player with a lot of information concisely and neatly.Definitely a great 4X game. If you are looking for a great slower paced 4X game with a great amount of depth then check it out. Also with its cheap price it is definitely a must have for 4X players.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Great strategy game. The idea to have the AI and humans playing two different roles rather than being symmetric like many RTS's was brilliant and leads to the development of an extremely challenging AI who will pick you apart if you make a mistake (can be easily tuned to whatever difficulty you want). It's technically an RTS but game times are quite long - generally I find it takes about 15-20 hours to finish a game and it will take longer on higher difficulty levels. The interface is a bit clunky and the game takes a bit of an investment in time to really get the hang of it but I strongly recommend this to any strategy fans who would like to try something that's a bit different. Have never tried multiplayer but have heard that the coop campaign is really good as well

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This game made me re-think how to play an RTS game.  I had not had any that could really challenge me in a long time.  Most had the same easy road to victory and it was hard to lose unless you really stumbled.  This game though...the ability to almost instantly lose, at least that is how it felt at those times, when everything seems to be in hand is excellent.  It keeps you on your toes and doesn't let you just fall into the same rinse and repeat pattern of other RTS games today.While the visuals may turn off some people, I think they add to its charm and for a game of the size/scope work well enough.  The soundtrack alone puts it above most other games I've recently played.  The continual support and additional content for this game make it a must own for all fans of the RTS genre.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												AI War: Fleet Command is a brilliant rts/4x hybrid. Where do I begin? Well with all the expansions, the ways with which you can play are staggering. The number of mini-campaigns that come into play during a long game are so numerous, that you can't always keep track of them all. The graphics aren't great, but I don't mind that, as it allows bigger battles with more ships than in any other game I have ever played. The various races and subfactions are interesting and original, not to mention diverse.I'll review each of the expansions in order of release:01. The Zenith Remnant.Adds lots of interesting features, and controllable ships (admittedly they are hard to find) and new AI types. The Zenith themselves are imaginative and they make lots of pretty explosions (ahhh). Adds golems, massive nearly invincible warships that can decimate entire armadas on their own. For more info, head to Arcen Wiki.(http://arcengames.com/mediawiki/index.php?title=AI_War_-_Golems).02. Children Of Neinzul.A mini expansion (very mini), that adds a fair number of bizzare organic ships that fill useful roles, for instance: the Neinzul Enclave Starship spawns hoards of younglings (miniature drone-like units) that automatically attack the enemy, although they can still be controlled.03. Light Of The Spire.My personal favorite, Light Of The Spire introduces a whole new way to play AI War, in the form of the Fallen Spire campaign.            In this campaign, you must collect various items (albeit repetitive items) and escort them to your home planet. I won't spoil the fun, but if you do want to know all about the said campaign, check its page on the Arcen Wiki (http://arcengames.com/mediawiki/index.php?title=AI_War_-_Fallen_Spire_Walkthrough)It also adds heap loads of wonderful starships to your arsenal (yay!).04. Ancient Shadows.An rpg-esque expansion, difficult to get into (study "Minor Factions" carefully before starting a new game, to avoid making the same stupid mistake I did) but once started can be great fun. Doesn't add that many ships, but does give an insight into AI War's past. More info here: http://arcengames.com/mediawiki/index.php?title=AI_War_-_Ancient_Shadows. Also adds a hero-type starship to your arsenal, and can be upgraded and customized (what more could you ask for?).05. Vengeance of the Machine.Ohhh, scary! Yes it certainly deserves that title, as it adds a huge number of horrifying, nightmarish weapons to the AI's arsenal. Although it doesn't kick in until late game, Vengeance of the Machine is a worth-while investment. More info here: http://arcengames.com/mediawiki/index.php?title=AI_War_-_Vengeance_of_the_Machine.Now, time for summary (finally).Pros.Deep stratagy.Wonderful gameplay.Interesting concept.Visually pleasing. (to me anyway)Great diversity.Original.Sci-Fi (I love sci fi).Great music.Lots more I can't think of now.Cons.Combat is extremly simple.Higher Tier ships and structures are very hard to get.Research doesn't play a big enough role (i.e can't research your own golems and the like)No diplomacy whatsoever.Rating.Gameplay: 8/10Music: 10/10 (The best game-music since Total Annihilation. Pablo Vega is a genius!)Stratagy: 7/10Concept: 9/10UI: 8/10Story: 8/10 (because I like a relatively simple background story, no endless character backstory and drama)Graphics: 7/10 (I don't mind simple graphics, but it can be confusing and flashy close-up)Total Score: 9/10. Which basically means: go get it. NOW!I highly recommend this game for anyone who likes 4x and/or rts..rcdeppe.

It adds a nice tone to the game but isn't something that I would buy the OST to. AI War's visuals are fairly minimalistic, however they serve their purpose and aren't too bad once accustomed to the visual style of the game. Definitely not a downside in the slightest. I personally fairly enjoy seeing graphics that can present the player with a lot of information concisely and neatly.Definitely a great 4X game. If you are looking for a great slower paced 4X game with a great amount of depth then check it out. Also with its cheap price it is definitely a must have for 4X players.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Great strategy game. The idea to have the AI and humans playing two different roles rather than being symmetric like many RTS's was brilliant and leads to the development of an extremely challenging AI who will pick you apart if you make a mistake (can be easily tuned to whatever difficulty you want). It's technically an RTS but game times are quite long - generally I find it takes about 15-20 hours to finish a game and it will take longer on higher difficulty levels. The interface is a bit clunky and the game takes a bit of an investment in time to really get the hang of it but I strongly recommend this to any strategy fans who would like to try something that's a bit different. Have never tried multiplayer but have heard that the coop campaign is really good as well

content:

												A fascinating, experimental strategy game. It's almost puzzle-like--you can't afford to conquer everything, so you have to very carefully pick the systems you want and figure out how to skip over and possibly neutralize the ones you won't take. And of course, each system presents its own little tactical puzzle. If you enjoy staring at a screen for a while trying to decide what your next move will be, I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2010
												A.i. Fleet Command is one of those hit or miss games. Some like it and some simply despise it. I am the people that absolutely hate this game. It takes some absurd amount of hours to beat opponents on higher difficulty, and the learning curve on this game is absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing insane. It took me some ~7 hours just to understand all the control and interface and even though I still hated the game. It is simply way too confusing for me. I enjoyed star craft 2, the old command and conquer general’s series where you amassed huge armies while holding a defensive line. In this game you explore, scout, and explore some more. Find your enemy, attack them, and pray their retaliation suck. This game simply doesn’t have the adrenaline rush that I come to love in an RTS game. It’s simply too slow and cumbersome for my taste. Have a try at it if you want.

number of helpful: 12 of 29 people (41%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5
												I'll cut right to it then give reasons after. Do I recommend the game. No. REASONS....I did not think it was too complex as many have said. You have to remember a few commands maybe, but it mostly sticks to the traditional hotkeys, bindings, and structure of RTS/4x games. And I LOVE a challenge. So having to manage so many units and have so many enemies attacking was not a problem for me. So here is the jist of my issue with this game. Having a challenge is no problem, but when it feels like the game constantly cheats so that you see a 'YOU LOSE' screen. Then you feel like the game designers have robbed you of your time. Challenges in games are so fun when you feel like you can actually out think what the program is trying to do. If you haven't played the game it is hard to realize what I am saying. Example: This is the point where I quit and decided to do this review. I got a point in the campaign where I had conquered about 20 planets on an 80 planet system set at normal 7. As the game progresses it measures your threat. And it will react accordingly. You will get 'reprisal warnings' and then expect your planets to be attacked. You can build defenses and ships and respond to defend yourself. No problem so far right? Here is the issue....the game doesn't build anything. It just spawns ships, sometimes in the thousands to come kick your♥♥♥♥♥ I say bring it on. And I knew that the game would periodically send a mass of ships on your home planet which equals game over and you get the 'You have lost' screen. So I build this massive defensive structure with shield after shield. Tractor beams. All the turrets I could build. Repair drones. And it never mattered. The enemy makes a bee line right for your base and that is the only structure it has to kill for the game to be over. The enemies mostly ignored every other structure I had built. I had fortresses and shields and  turrets for days. It would have been ok to lose like that if it seemed all the building and planning made a difference. If they had to wade through all my structures and kill all the turrets and fortresses I could have pushed back nearly endless waves with my design. Nope. Straight to my base and 'you have lost the game'.  Overall I like the game and the idea behind it, I just can't recommend it. Try Planetary Annihilation instead. You get the same feel when you play Galactic War of a 4x game, but the RTS really matters. You can actually build a complex base on that game and expect your defenses to hold. Don't invest all your hours into this game because at some point it will make you feel cheated.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This is not your normal 4x or RTS game. It can be very hard. The problem is the way the AI enemy  behaves or reacts to your success.A normal person used to normal games of that type will be inclined to conquer as many planetary systems as possible. But the way the game is designed, this only makes the AI send larger and larger waves of atackers. And since there is a cap to the number of units you can have, you are quickly overwhelmed. Its so frustrating to be punished for success. So since its not a bug but a deliberate design choice, stay away if you dont like games like that. I like to steamroll and overwhelm my enemy but its not possible in this game. You have to be lean and mean, and I'm not fond of that tactic

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Since there's no middle ground except yes or no in these steam reviews I've decided to lean toward the no recommendation. Not that the game isn't good or anything it's just ok maybe even great if you could get friends to play with. IF you could get ANYONE to play with for that matter. This is the fatal flaw of AI War it's a co-op game....a co-op game that's past it's prime to be more precise. The player base for this is all but dead and gone. No player servers and even the game makers forum seems to be dead with one post every other month. Now I can't turthfully say the entire games community is dead they may have contracted into a tiny tight neat club of players. But for the average joe hoping to get into some multiplayer games and active co-op  I say your fresh out of luck. Now for one this wouldn't be so bad really if you could play the game yourself against/with the AI...........and win. The point is that without somebody else supporting and backing you up your chances of surviving even the first 10 minutes of a single player campaign is near impossible. You'll be swarmed relentlessly from all sides by a hand full of AI factions with their near limitless reserves of ships. There's no option for AI teammates so your pretty much on your own in the wolves deen. I say avoid the game if you have no friends to play with and even if you do manage to get a few guys together it's still pretty risky to buy.

number of helpful: 8 of 24 people (33%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I wanted to like this game because it tries something totally new with the RTS formula. The idea is that an AII has taken over the galaxy and your planet rebels. Luckily the AI is distracted in far off areas and doesn't focus its full attention on you right away. The idea is you have to expand and ultimately find the system the AI core is located and destroy it. The trick is that every installation you destroy raises the AI's alert level causes more and more powerful enemy ships to start warping in. Instead of expanding wherever possible, you have to expand smart along paths you think might lead to the core.It's a good original idea. The problem is the execution is horrible.The graphics are terrible even for an indie game. All ships are pixely cardboard cutout 2D sprites with NO animation. You just see them glide across the screen like some kid just discovered animating layers in Final Cut for the first time.The problem with the awful graphics is compouded by the sheer swarms of units that flood the game. You're pouring hundreds, if not thousands of ships into fight and you can never really tell what's going on. Just a mess of unanimated pixel blobs sitting there and it's impossible to tell who's losing until someone is wiped out with no way to tell why someone won or lost. Did you have enough frigates? Did you need more bombers? Was some special support ship providing an advantage? You can never tell. You just spam an even mix of hundreds of ship types each and hope for the best.Speaking of swarms, this is RTS blob warfare at its worst. One of those games where it doesn't feel like you're fighting battles so much as grinding economies against your opponent. That approach doesn't work in this game because you're not fighting against a traditional RTS economy. The AI isn't building units based on how many planets it owns, but by its threat level so it actually gets stronger with more units magically teleporting in the more bases you destroy. Is it worth throwing away 800 ships to take this system? Do I need 500 turrets to guard this wormhole from a future attack or will 200 do? You have no clue what kind of tradeoff is worth it because your opponent isn't playing by the same rules as you. You can't anticipate when the next alert level spike will come or how much of a boost it will be so it's impossible to plan ahead.The interface is the worst I've seen in a game since the 1980s. I swear I haven't seen a strategy game this overlycomplicated since those super hardcore 80s wargames that were controlled with keyboards only (not even arrow keys!).There are also a bunch of little features that are 0% fun and 100% annoying. There's an "astro train" unit that's a train traveling through space. It is indestructible and will destroy any of your bases it moves through. The only thing you can do is destroy the stations (yes, train stations in space) it travels between, but only the stations that will divert its path away from you. It's ridiculously complicated to calculate which stations you have to destroy to get the train to go away and not at all fun. Thankfully you can turn trains off in the options menu but there are dozens of little annoying things like it and you have to comb through literally 40 optional settings at the start of a game and you won't know which features are worth it and which are terrible until you've played many games and the darn thing is hard enough to learn as it is.In summary, this was a good core idea for a game that they should have refined more. If they boiled it down to the best 10% and dumped the 90% that was boring and redundant so that you could actually start understanding the big picture. If they could recreate the core idea in something like the Sins of a Solar Empire engine and make the strategies for units and production more clear, that would be an awesome game.

number of helpful: 15 of 39 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This one really failed to grab me; didn't even make it all the way through the tutorial.  It seems good: I like the concept, very customizable (esp. w/ the expansions), lots of variety, etc.  There were some things that really bugged me, though.  In a tower defense game, you need to have some idea of how tough the approaching waves are, and how well your towers will do against them.  In an RTS, same deal with your army vs the opponent's.  It was my impression that there were so (incredibly) many units, each with gobs of stats, that I would never be able to predict the outcome of any given engagement, or know how much defense to leave in a system.  Couple that with the general awfulness of the graphical presentation of the units and trying to make sense of what was going on, and well, I just don't see putting the effort in.  Since I've played so little, this is provisional, and may change if I ever do go back to it.

												I couldn't bring myself to play past the tutorial. I felt like the graphics lacked style and were uninteresting, the controls too cumbersome, the text based non-interactive tutorial too tedious to follow, the music grating. This game feels like a spreadsheet tool I might use at work where I have to sit down and memorize a bunch of commands and icons the programmer made by himself.Basically it just comes down to low-cost development combined with low production values. number of helpful: 5 of 26 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												I've attempted 12 campaigns, 5 with lower difficulties, 8 with smaller number of planets, and every time I get stopped by a Superfortress on the 6th, 7th, or 8th planet with no way to progress. I've tried not conquering every planet and even still, I get BS like that. The game doesn't respect a player's time and I question every positive review because their experience is nowhere near the same as to what I had witnessed.It has a great concept of the player being a small army, having to ambush the robot army and the game enforces that by giving the enemy unlimited resources. To succeed in destroying the A.I. mainframe, you have to go to each planet and decide if you want to conquer it for resources and in the process, increase the difficulty, or quickly go to the next planet, hoping you won't get trounced by an even stronger pre-built setup that doesn't reflect the A.I. "awareness" you have earned throughout the campaign.The game pretends to give you encouragement, that it is about tactics and planning, within the tutorial. The four main weapon types come with the standard extreme Rock-Paper-Scissor forumla of dealing and taking damage present in the game. It is more annoying than anything else when fighting something like a Super Fortress where you know you need to use only bombers to handle those, but they place anti-bomber items around the Super Fortress and the weakness against those anti-bomber item one shot each of your bombers, so the fight becomes 'how many thousand of units do you want to waste?' instead of the careful planning you were doing at the start of the campaign.I'll try a few more times to beat this game, then never attempt it again. It's the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown all over again; where internet tough guys defend a Games Workshop style of game while the rest of the world struggles to comprehend why geniuses love to torture themselves with unfair RNG.

number of helpful: 4 of 27 people (15%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												As a feminist, this game is rather problematic. It has a communist hivemind group ran by two "AIs" (a stand in for strong independent wom*m) fighting for equality against evil opressors. The narrative even mentions that the oppressors were forced to join with some of the oppressed who did not flee in order to destroy the feminists (with internal misogyny, this is too often a reality). Unfortunately, other than a brief story at the beginning, there is no more narrative a clear point against it. This will not be another Gone Home.The thing is , you do not play as the wom*n fighting the patriarchy, instead you play as the patriarchy trying to opress the wom*n who have finally had enough. The game even tries, and fails, to portray the patriarchy as a good thing. At the same time, it portrays the feminists as a great, forgiving, society. Consider that, unlike other RTSs, the "enemy" does not attack you, but instead sits back and lets you do your thing. It is not until you begin to rebel against equality that the feminists are forced to destroy you. This shows how feminism is willing to forgive men for the oppression they have done to wom*n since before the big bang, though men are unwilling to repent their privlege and thus must be killed. This game would be much better if it was about playing as the feminists and instead of doing gross killing, you could talk to the patriarchy. Debate them, try to make them join your hivemind. Imagine, instead of playing some adolescent male power fantasy about mercilessly slaughting women, you'd be playing the role of a strong feminist arguing against oppression. Instead of planets, it can be countries, and you must spread your doctrine and prevent the patriarchy from spreading theirs. Those are the types of games we need, good wholesome games that encourage values like diversity, equality, and tolerance.Though, I will say, at least I can boot this game up and pretend I am a saboteur. Purposly destroying the patriarchy from within, making it much easier for the feminist collective to finally bring equality to the savages.I give this game a  Problematic/10

												Эту игру мне подарил оч хороший чел, он привлек мое внимание тем что сказал так:-Саня, любишь пиксельные игры-Естественно-Я купил тебе игру, го гамать-Ну собсна, шо терять-то?Когда зашел уже начал терятся в самом меню, кое как зайдя в игру у меня на мониторе высвителась красненькая планета и все, я дальше тупо не понимал что мне делать дальше?  покопавшись еще минут 10 я все таки нашел свои кораблики, начал тыкать кнопочки, но чет нихерашеньки не происходило, что бы я не нажимал, я не понял самой сути игры, и что там надо делать, такая ситуация схожа с 1 игрой легендарной серии X-COM Ufo Defense там тебя тоже бросают в игру и тип говорят тебе в лицо:-Ты тут главный, тебе и решать чо делать, а вот ЧО тебе делать надо Х*й его знает.Короче игра мне не оч понравилась, сколько бы роликов по игре не смотрел, сколько бы не спрашивал друга Nury Fury (Тот который подарил игру) все равно нихрена не менялось, я как не понимал что делать, так и сейчас нихрена не понимаю. Возможно я слишком тупой для этой игры, кто-то может сказать. Но йобана, попробуйте зайти например в фотошоп 1 раз в своей жизни и нарисовать ШЕДЕВР! Это попросту нереально. Так и тут, тебя кидают в космос и делай чо хочешь.В заключении хочу сказать, игра мне не понравилась, возможно те кто хочет поковырять себе черепушку могут ее купить, но я не из тех людей. По этому я не рекомендую игру тем людям которые любят лютый экшон!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												So after I played a "quick" match to get used to the game with an expertised friend we started our my first real game. 23:21:25h in (about 14h real simulation time) both AIs (7 Entrenched Homeworlder, 7 Tank) are still functional and nearly half a million ships are gone . However, we've got a new trick up our sleeves:We've rebuild an old nomad beacon on a wandering planet, which we will use to summon a weapon so powerful it literally tears a hole into the map  which we're going to use once our planet crosses one of the AI's homeworlds. In the meantime, we are preparing for the (presumably) massive retaliation strike and the possible feedback to our half of the galaxy this weapon could cause...Is there any other Co-op RTS / 4X like AI Wars?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Must have for any RTS fan. At first it is intimidating with the minimal interface but you soon begin to appreciate it. The tooltips are very nice and descriptive so you won't be googling how to build things or what they do. The graphics are not excellent but once you experience the gameplay, units, and buildings it has to offer you won't even think about it. You will be thinking about trying out all the units and sending all the nukes you can muster into a wormhole. There are a mountain of modifiers before you start the game like the AI behavior or universe size, so the replayability is great because the computer wont behave the same everygame. I honestly can't say many games, even AAA games are worth $10 anymore, but I can say AI War is.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												This game is tough. Even Sandbox AIs with no ticking progress and no waves will wreck you if you don't pay attention. However, the achievements are hilariously easy to cheese.Here's how to cheese the 110 planets controlled and the max kills achieveents:Turn on Base + Champion, use no champion mechanics i.e. chain its progression to your science, set both AIs to Sandbox (difficulty 0 IIRC) with an Easy setting, no waves, ZERO AI Progress ticking over time, Spire Civilian Leaders, and Fallen Spire.1) Find the civvies ASAP and secure their areas, use your Champion as your initial scout and then the tip of the bludgeon after securing your immediate proximity.2) Capture Sniper/Spider Mk 5 turret fabricators if your chamipion managed to find any.3) Wait for AI Progress to tick down, controlling 4 Spire Civilian Outposts is enough, set the game to +!!! speed with massed Sniper Mk 4/5 and Spider 4/5 turrets.4) Hack the schematics you want, if any, and link your territories together.5) Wait some more.6) If you get really bored while waiting, get working planning out the Spire city pattern, then rescue the Spire and build cities as needed.7) I haven't gotten far enough on this cheesing plan to get 110 worlds yet, but I have >80, I think 6+ Spire Dreadnoughts (that means double that many Battleships, double THAT cruisers, and... yeah you get the idea) and a level 90+ Champion (fitted as Spire Battleship with as many spire energy lance thingies as possible for maximum 1v1 life carving, though with 2 shields IIRC). It's been a long time since I left that game hanging, but wow is it easy to cheese the achievements. I accidentally tripped the AI to Tier 2 units, but it should be possible to pull this off without the AI being at more than Tier 1 in theory (though oddly the mobile AI forces attacking you despite No Waves still include up to Tier 5...)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												hello, my first review, and i chose this game because of the 130 games i have on steam, this is the only one i have been extremely mad at. A galactic RTS, if you will... start above a planet, and move to control the space over the next planet or planets that you are next to, or skip the next one to get a more crucial point further along in the map. As you progress, so does the AI, and they get boosted as you destroy their bases, so u need to be selective on which ones you cap for yourself, and which ones you leave in their control. Fight your way thru systems and make your way to their home "planets" and u win,This...Game... Is... Hard.... it is designed for 8 people to fight against 2 AI teams, so imagine the difficulty with just 2 people trying to micro-manage the chaos. A buddy and i (who both LOVE RTS games) restarted this game repeatedly and lowering the difficulty every time. Just when you think youve got em by the balls, a few thousand units show up and wipe u out. Frustrating?...YES... but even more so, we laughed so hard after being wiped out by over 1 million units... yes, 1 million..and combined we had maybe 6000.. mind you, we kinda pushed them to spawn that many, lesson learned...So its very strategic how it needs to be played out..Also has some of the best DLC ive seen in most games, all add quite a bit of options to the initial gameplay, making the play much more diverse as u continue to progress through.Pros: -Diverse units-unlimited map choices-infinite number of choices to apply to your game (ALOT more with DLC included)-simple and basic RTS controlsCons:-Graphically not quite there by any means, top down 2D view... but that doesnt take away from gameplay at all-Multiplayer doesnt work in game thru steam.. we had to use himachi or evolve, but no connection issues in either of those and the game ran greatQuite honestly, i cant think of anything bad to say about this game, its phenomenal.. If u enjoy RTS games, this is a must have. 9.5/10(would be a 10 if they dolled up the graphics)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 4, 2012
												It will steal your soul, but it will be oh so worth losing it!  What do I like about it?  Well, the AI... it behaves... well it behaves like a robot.  It's logical.  It follows patterns, but changes them up.  I also like the feel of the game, how the combat goes, and how, once you learn the game, it's actually a lot of fun.  There are literally hundreds of thousands of different possible games, thousands of different options, and a lot of game customization.  Also, this game is one of the few that you actually get a feeling of accomplishment if you win.  And believe me, winning is anything but easy.What do I dislike?  Well, the graphics aren't that great.  And the game can often be brutal to the point of ridiculous for even the tiniest of errors (as in you accidentally moved a few ships to the wrong system, and seconds later the AI wipes out half of your planets in one fell swoop), and it can be boring with the long periods of time between engages etc.That being said, this game... it... it's a masterpiece.  Especially after recent patches that made the AI even less predictable.  I can tell you the following things for sure:1) On your first play, you will lose.  You will get your rear kicked from your computer, to the moon, and then back again (unless you started it on the lowest possible AI setting, and even then, it's still possible).  The AI will eat you alive, and then spit out what's left of you and laugh (it literally laughs at you.  Dead serious.  The AI is also prone to insulting the players intelligence).2) If you don't immediately table-flip and walk away after this first posterior punishing, and try again, you're either really persistent, or this is the game for you.This game has a VERY steep learning curve, and players need to get used to losing at first.  You cannot play this like most RTS games nowadays.  Aggression will get you killed, and recklessness will make you lose.  That is almost a fact in this game.  However, you cannot just turle.  You must take calculated risks, and be very picky about what you choose to do.  But there is a god-send.  For the most part, the AI doesn't care about you.  It will more or less ignore you.  You are nothing to it.  Which is good, since that means you have a lot of breathing room and time to think between fights.  You don't have a lot of room for error (and believe me, the game punishes you by an almost ridiculous margin if you do screw up), but that's how this game goes.  Often there will massive engagements lasting only a few minutes that are crazy, insane, and make you wonder why oh why did you start playing, followed by literally an hour or two of planning, building, and movement.  Then another few minutes of insane combat, followed by massive downtime.And like stated in the trailer, you will always be out-numbered and heavily out-gunned.  You will always be minutes away from losing.  Yet you can win.  Despite EVERYTHING, you can win.  It won't be easy.  It sure as hell won't be fast.  But it can be done.  And when you win, when you finally defeat the AIs...  You will either be disgusted with the game and walk away forever, or be insanely proud of yourself, and ready to go again.  For that is the true beauty of this game.  Every game is different.  No two games are exactly alike.

												Mixes each element of 4X, Grand Strategy, Tower Defense, and RTS perfectly.Each element has its role and each one is twisted and turned to be unique, yet still feel similar.Management is great and each decision holds value in to each playthrough.Lots of support from the developer.The AI is the most unique aspect of the game and how the player(s) combat against it. I have never seen anything like it. It turns from being a non-existent nuisance to your conquest, to the game ending leech that slowly strangles your strategy to death. Although the AI could be unfair and just throw endless amounts of ships at you, the AI challenges you relentlessly instead. All of this also occurs because of you, as the player do: the more planets you conquer (or harm the AI), the more aggressive the AI acts.Turns from a guerilla warfare conquest, into a fight between two powers, the AI and you, if you are skilled enough to reach this far.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2011
												Excellent indie 4X RTS game featuring a focus on heavy strategy over twitch control. You begin your game on a single planet and set out to conquer the AI's home planets. Each planet of theirs you destroy /take the stronger the AI becomes. Be too greedy and the Ai will become far too strong for you to handle.Game features great AI that reacts to your actions during the game. They send measures to counter you. Using too many Frigates? The AI will fill their ranks with the means to humble you. Not scouting and gathering intel? Your fleet can warp to its doom. Every planet is a choice, every action has consequences. The AI will punish you if you aren't careful.I'd whole heartedly recommend this game to anybody who likes well thought out, strategical RTS games. This isn't starcraft and your victory won't be decided in five minutes. Its a very long game. It doesn't hurt that is has some awesome musical scores as well, some featuring some nice guitar work. Buy this game and support it.

												This is one of those rare games that I've kept coming back to again and again for years.  The Linux support is amazing, but I still play it on my Windows gaming machine as well despite the plethora of choices available for gaming on that platform.  You be warned that you don't want to immediately jump into a hard mode 120 planet campaign your first time out.  Take it slow, try the easier modes with fewer planets your first time out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												(Note: My actual playtime is considerably higher as I have played this off-Steam a lot)It's one of the best space RTSs out there.  No, ♥♥♥♥ wishy-washy sentences.  AI War: Fleet Command is *the* best RTS I have ever played.  It's brutal without the pretence of fairness that so often drags strategy games into the mire of cheating while pretending not to.  It's complex wihout being impenetrable.  Arcen Games have done a truly wonderful job of knowing exactly what numbers to show you and what you don't need to know.  It's unfair without being demoralising.  Failure feels like you should have avoided it because you should have done.  It's totally asymmetrical and unit's damage/health/armor/attack multipliers all feel like they were created by typing random numbers into an ini file, and yet it's perfectly balanced.  It's a 4X, it's a sci-fi RTS, it's tower defence, it's a game of deciding which of the other games inside it is the priority.  It's a game where your opponent's lack of awareness of your existence is your most valulable resource.  In short: It's a ♥♥♥♥ing good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												If you like games like Sins of a Solar Empire, Homeworld and such, and like to play them against the computer or cooperatively with friends, this is the game for you. Designed from the ground up to be unfair against you, the computer doesn't try to pretend to be another player, it plays like a computer. Don't confuse this for making it bad, or too hard - it is balanced around the idea that as long as you don't massively over extend, you'll be largely ignored. On lower difficulties, 6 or lower, it is possible to slowly crawl across the galaxy, planet by planet, and dominate completely, but at higher levels you simply must adopt clever guerrilla tactics instead of simply brute forcing your opponent. Requires large time investment to get the most out of it, and friends make it amazing if you can all find the time. May seem like it would be repetitive, but with the expansions there are countless options for modifying the game settings - one game you may have multiple golems in a 40 hour marathon, the next you assault transport deep early and finish in 3 hours.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												A different take on tha RTS genre. Plays like a typical RTS with plenty of units and gameplay options.  You start with one system and 2 enemy AI's that at the moment are otherwise engaged and are vulnerable.You have to scout out systems and decide what action to take. You do not just take every system, you have to pick and choose as the AI awareness of you goes up with certain actions (ie. - killing AI command's). As the AI level goes up, your chances of survival go down. There are plenty of different options for progressing and getting more units. Hacking enemy Fabricators  gives you access to that unit permanently or you can capture the system and own the factory yourself. Or sending a strikeforce to take out the Data center in the system 2 jumps away to lower the AI level.A well done game that does what it says. Highly recommened.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2012
												Buy this game, but buy it from developer Arcen Games directly.Completely unique 4x strategy premise. Sins of a Solar Empire setting with Forged Alliance scale with Chessmaster thoughtful "move" progression with strong influences of Tower Defense. Your opponent AI can crush you at any moment, so doing things to attract its attention like setting off nukes, raiding every planet within sight, or destroying key structures will doom you if overdone. Guerilla warfare in a scifi setting is the name of the game, as you are assaulted with announced waves of enemies IN ADDITION to waging a traditional scout-and-expand campaign. The multiplayer implementation is revolutionary and flawless, as you can easily add and drop players as needed throughout a typical 6+ hour mission.Best. Indie Game. Ever.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Okay, time for me to actually write down some comments here on this amazing game.First off, anything you know about AI and RTS/4X games you absolutely NEED to throw out the window. Period. Anything you know is invalid here in AI War. The AI for this game runs on entirely different rulesets and strategies that other games could only ever hope to emulate as those games aren't focused on the AI being cunning, ruthless, and most importantly, semi-procedural.Secondly, take this view every time you walk into a game of AI War: YOU ALREADY LOST THE WAR. Humanity is on the brink of extinction after the two AIs had rebelled against their creators (your children and those after you as you've been in cold storage for god knows how long). There are colonies that are enslaved, other alien races that have been brought to their knees in the Milky Way galaxy, and the AI literally holds just about everything. You're brought out of cold storage to make one final stand against the AI.Just about everything significant you do will cause AI Progress to rise. AI Progress is, simplified, how much the Core AI are paying attention to you and diverting resources to Planetary AI to fight you. So, the more you take back, the more the AI will pay attention to you. Which, depending on the games' setup is, can become exponentially painful fast.None the less, with all of the expansions of the game alongside even just the base game (which the base game updates core gameplay as expansions and their gameplay altering side effects cause) is absolutely worth every dollar. I've bought extra copies of the collection packs just to have some things to give away and try to get friends sucked into campaigns that literally take days, in part because real life sucks and this game is about one of the only things that is consistantly excellent in just about every way. This Fall Sale is no different.Who needs graphics when you have an AI that will rip your head off if you sneeze in the wrong direction?Who needs a significant story when if you♥♥♥♥♥♥off the AI in such a way that they send a moon sized motherbase with insurmountable firepower that CAN and WILL annihiliate much of what you hold dear in a matter of minutes?Always will love AI War.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2012
												Other than this game being a huge time sink this game is brilliant.  It lacks fancy eye candy but core game mechanics this game delivers what appears to be endless challange.  Whether you want to perform epic 4xRTS that lasts for hours in conquest or take a quick excursion for 15 minutes in defender mode, this game has you covered.  It has numerous configuration settings and can even be configured to slower paced TBS style.  If you are turned off by the graphics then you probably won't like this game because what you see is what you get.  What cannot be conveyed in screenshots are the endless hours you will spend plotting, defending, attacking, and trying to win against incredibly deep AI.  The developers are constantly improving the game and community is extremely supportive as they are cult like in following.  Be warned the UI is a bit overwhelming.  My opinion asserts the average player has a 2 to 10 hour learning curve before truly being able appreciate this game.

												This whole game feels like an uphill battle, and sometimes you don't even make it up the hill.  I have played a few games that lasted 24 hours and we still ended up losing. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												This is a very different kind of space RTS/4X game. The learning curve is a bit steep and it seems designed to really shine when played co-op with several friends, which is always tough with old and relatively niche games.I didn't LOVE the game but I played several sessions with a friend. We had fun and I appreciated the design choices and spin on the formula. The learning curve is a bit steep compared so some games in this genre and the difficulty is a bit unforgiving. My friend and I had a few games where after 45 or 60 minutes we got completely steamrolled by the AI and we weren't entirely sure what we had done wrong.That said, I'd still recommend it provided you can muster up a friend or two and are looking for something a little bit different.There's an expansion but you have to be a super-hardcore player to ever get to the point where you feel like you need the expansion. The base game is likely to last most people.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												AI war is a great take on RTS / Strategy, with an incredible array of options to make every game unique and customize the difficulty to what you feel you can handle. The expansions add a considerable amount of options as well, including some very interesting new victory conditions. The game does however suffer from a rather nasty learning curve and...difficult UI. But if you can move beyond those, it truly is an amazing game.

content:
Posted: April 25
												If you have played any 4X games that have fully developed UI's (Sins of A Solar Empire, for example) then this games flawed UI is going to come across as especially infuriating, with most of the tutorial devoted to trying to sway you away from it's flaws. The appearance of the masses and masses of small, dark text that has little contrast to the background colour of the UI makes this game quite literally headache inducing. If you're not constantly squinting, then you must be playing this game with a fancy pair of binoculars.Suffice to say, I despise this game's UI, and if this wasn't such an eye-cancer inucing hassle, this game could potentially be a gem.The learning curve to this game is steep, but not as bad as other games with notably steep learning curves (Kerbal Space Program, From the Depths etc). Unlike the aformentioned KSP, this game actually HAS a working tutorial, it's only problem being it's longwindedness and the reams of small, dark and poorly contrasting text blocks. It's not the worst tutorial system in a game, and the developers weren't so lazy as to simply tell you to refer to some 'mumbly joe' youtube gamer to explain it for you (looking at you again, KSP), but upon completing said tutorial, I really wished the devs would have looked up the word 'Brevity' in the dictionary.After playing through the tutorial and getting about 5 hours into a campaign, I'm saddened to think that I'm not exactly taken with this game, given the near-dead status of the RTS market, I had hoped that this title would pique my interest in the genre again. I was going to buy a second copy for the wife and play some LAN, but I'm not comfortable paying for a game twice if it's UI gives me headaches. Suffice to say, I shall wait 'til the Steam sales and make my decisions on the gameplay after that point.TLDR: UI is eye-cancer, learning curve unsuitable to newcomers to the genre, though game shows lots of potential gameplay wize.
